column17: What is your current traction over the last 6 months?
column18: How many customers do you have? Please describe your sales pipeline today.
column19: How many of them are paying and what is the current pricing structure?
column20: What is the typical sales cycle you have and who needs to be involved in the buying decision?

column26: What are your company's greatest barriers to success?

column30: If you were referred by in network contact, what is their name?

By submitting this application, you acknowledge that the SemperVirens Accelerator Program (together with its affiliates, “SV”) may collect, store, and process the information and materials you provide for the purpose of evaluating your application. We may share your application materials with our affiliates, advisors, employees and representatives as part of the evaluation process. While we take reasonable steps to protect the confidentiality of your application, we cannot guarantee full confidentiality of information submitted. You should only share information that you are comfortable disclosing for evaluation purposes. 

By submitting this application, you acknowledge and agree that SV may, now or in the future work with other startups or businesses that operate in similar fields or industries. Submission of an application does not create any obligation of confidentiality, partnership, or exclusivity between you and SV. If accepted into the SemperVirens Accelerator Program, additional information may be required which will be subject to customary confidentiality obligations. 

For the avoidance of doubt, you will retain all rights, title and interest in and to any intellectual property and/or proprietary information contained in your application. Submission of an application does not grant SV any ownership or license rights to your Intellectual Property. If you are accepted into the program, any use of IP will be subject to mutually agreed written terms.

column3: GTMFlow equips executives and organizations with the mindset and tools to thrive through curveballs—unexpected challenges that disrupt performance. Our executive cancer coaching is a scalable benefit that supports employees navigating diagnosis or caregiving, helping them balance work, treatment, and communication to stay resilient and productive.
column7:
A cancer diagnosis is profoundly destabilizing—especially for executives responsible for leading teams, driving strategy, and managing critical customer and investor relationships. These leaders are expected to deliver clarity, momentum, and stability—while suddenly navigating medical decisions, emotional strain, and physical disruption. Most employers offer insurance and clinical support, but they lack real-time, experienced, executive-centric coaching to help executives process the diagnosis, communicate with stakeholders, and balance their dual responsibilities to their health and their company.

Without targeted support, executives often withdraw, make reactive decisions, or disappear from the business when their leadership is most needed. This creates ripple effects across teams and priorities, leading to unnecessary leaves, stalled initiatives, and cultural instability. GTMFlow closes this gap by delivering executive-grade coaching that helps leaders develop a plan, communicate confidently, and stay engaged—so they can protect their health and business continuity.
column9: All coaching content and delivery tools are developed in-house by the founder, based on a proprietary coaching method and lived experience. No external developers involved although we leverage GenAI platforms such as ChatGPT, NotebookLM, and Anthropic.
column10:
1 – Solopreneur (Founder-led: coaching delivery, operations, go-to-market).

This product is at the conceptual, pre-launch process. With demand, we have a pipeline of prospective coaches (former executives who have faced cancer) who will be trained in the approach and scale the delivery of the service. 

We are also in discussions with OpenNetworks.org to offer our service through their platform where the platform will trigger notification of a qualified individual with a cancer diagnosis so that private contact can be made within the first 48 hours of diagnosis.
column12: No - we've been testing the needs and packaging with inbound referrals (2-3 per week)
column13: Mid-size to large companies (50–5,000+ employees) that want to offer a modern, meaningful benefit to support executives facing cancer and provide business continuity and excellent guidance. Their most significant pain point: lack of proactive, human-centered support for navigating work and treatment, resulting in presenteeism, burnout, and attrition.
column14: Over 2 million U.S. cancer diagnoses each year; 46% are working adults. Employers with 50+ employees represent over 100 million covered lives. We estimate our SAM at $3B for cancer-specific coaching benefits.
column15: Well-being apps, EAPs, and navigation platforms (e.g. Spring Health, Included Health) address mental or clinical support but don’t provide practical, confidential coaching for how to stay engaged at work post-diagnosis. They miss the first 48–72 hours—when employees most need support planning what to say, how to manage expectations, and how to show up at work.
column16: We operate as an employee benefit provider. Employers pay a low monthly per-employee-per-month (PEPM) fee. There are different rates if you want the benefit accessible to all employees—not just executives—when they or someone they care for is diagnosed with cancer. Employees activate the benefit confidentially and receive 1:1 coaching, communication planning, decision support, and access to tools that help them stay engaged and healthy through treatment.
column17: Strong evidence of need and that the support within the first 4 weeks is the crucial period for these individuals to communicate, set expectations, and manage work and health responsibilities.
column20: Sales cycle is 45–90 days. Decision-makers include People/HR leaders, Total Rewards leaders, and occasionally CFOs or founders. Cancer support is often an emotional and strategic decision, requiring education and real-world framing.  Our best prospects are executives who themselves have navigated a cancer journey and recognize the immediacy and disruption it causes.
column21: Growing demand for targeted benefits and inclusive support programs. Post-pandemic benefits trends emphasize mental health, chronic care, and employee advocacy. Cancer impacts 1 in 2 families—HR leaders are actively seeking scalable solutions with a personal, human touch. We’ve received strong endorsements from oncologists, patient advocates, and benefits leaders.
column22: Self-funded. No outside investors to date.
column23: My costs to date are very low and my approach to scale is not capital intensive so my current runway is infinite. That said, a more structured benefit will need more infrastructure and we will need investment to create the secure infrastructure for our corporate clients.

column28:
One of the most powerful insights I’ve received came from a newly diagnosed executive who said, “I’m not afraid of the cancer—I’m afraid of how people will treat me once they know.” That stayed with me. The stress of navigating perceptions, expectations, and potential marginalization at work often outweighs the medical fear in those early days.

This insight helped me realize that communication isn’t just a tactical issue—it’s an emotional lifeline. I pivoted GTMFlow to address not only decision-making and productivity, but also the deep need for guidance around disclosure, relationship dynamics, and workplace identity after a diagnosis. Our coaching now starts by helping clients build a communication plan rooted in clarity, confidence, and compassion—because the moment they share their diagnosis often defines how supported (or isolated) they’ll feel going forward.

column3: DoktorConnect utilizes cutting-edge technology to predict, prevent, treat diseases, and track real-time progress, improving longevity and well-being.
column7: My friend Jim died at the age of 42. Jim had diabetes. This happened because of an autoimmune disease that affected his pancreas and unable to produce insulin that led to a type 1 diabetes, and didn't know it until it was too late. He found out because of a wound he sustained at work that would not heal. At the time of his passing, he was an amputee and severely depressed. He left two daughters and his wife with exciting data about his business and finances, but Jim was not tracking a single data about his health. Since that happened, l vowed that there would not be another Jim. This is the story of 1 out 4 American

column15:
Function, Superpower and other longevity medicine providers. But we got the source and juice to hit a home run in this space 

Our Solution

DoktorConnect offers a comprehensive digital health platform that leverages personalized medical care through wellness-based assessments, genetic analysis, mental health screening, and advanced technologies. By analyzing genetic data and wellness metrics, we create evidence-based lifestyle management plans for individuals. Our platform enables virtual consultations with licensed doctors, therapists, dieticians, and health coaches, along with real-time vital signs tracking using smart medical IoT devices. We also integrate AI-driven methodologies to promote healthy behaviors, lifestyle modifications, medication management, and tailored exercise regimens.
